children.name: Existing variables, alternative descriptions
children.content:
Following the emergence of new variables proposed by participants,
additional insights arise from the ways in which they reinterpret and
refine the variables already included in the activity. In fact,
participants also offered alternative and nuanced descriptions that
deepen the understanding of certain properties. These contributions
build directly on the previous section by showing how familiar variables
can expand in meaning when grounded in lived experience and personal
perception.

The variable brightness, for instance, was described in three distinct
ways by the same participant (P4, WS1): as saturation, referring to the
intensity of colour and its vividness; as the black-and-white contrast,
where brightness is detached from colour altogether; and as chiaroscuro,
or the interplay of light and dark. These varying definitions highlight
the need for flexibility in interpreting visual properties, particularly
when linked to personal perception or metaphorical association.
Similarly, viscosity was clarified through a comparison between water
and maple syrup (P20, WS3), establishing a spectrum of fluid thickness
that could be used to convey sensations such as ease or resistance in
bodily processes.

Finally, the variable permeability was discussed through material
comparisons. A participant (P5, WS1) described it using the metaphor of
a net with different mesh sizes to indicate how easily liquid passes
through, while another (P3, WS1) compared foam and wood to distinguish
between absorbent and non-absorbent materials. Overall, these insights
underline the participants’ active role in contextualising variables,
often grounding them in tangible analogies that connect material
properties to bodily or experiential sensations.

children.name: Sensory, visual, and literal strategies for identification
children.content:
Participants employed a wide range of strategies to identify and
associate variables with symptoms, drawing on tactile exploration,
metaphorical reasoning, and visual comparison. A frequent approach
involved translating bodily sensations into material features. In these
cases, specific qualities of the materials were interpreted as analogues
of physiological experiences. For example, friction encountered when
manipulating a material was linked to the discomfort of urination,
illustrating how tactile resistance became a metaphor for pain (P2,
WS1). Similarly, the texture and permeability of certain materials were
associated with difficulty in urination (P5, WS1), showing how sensory
cues could evoke underlying physiological constraints.

Identification also emerged through strategies based on contrast.
Participants rejected features such as smoothness (P9, WS2) or
pronounced three dimensionality (P17, WS3) when these characteristics
were perceived as incompatible with symptoms like itching or discomfort.
These contrasts guided participants toward selecting variables that more
closely aligned with their embodied experiences.

Literal associations formed another strategy, especially when variables
such as temperature were used to represent fever. This direct
correspondence was viewed by some as too explicit or didactic (P2, WS1),
yet it nonetheless remained a meaningful way for participants to
articulate internal sensations through material form. Aesthetic
considerations also shaped variable selection. One participant, for
example, explained how cutting polyester at an angle exposed three
dimensional contours that could more effectively express certain
symptoms than smoother finishes (P13, WS2).

Colour proved especially influential because of its strong visual
salience. Participants used it to represent symptoms that carry
immediate visual markers, such as blood in urine, demonstrating how
vividness and recognisability can guide material choice (P2, WS1).

Taken together, these strategies show how participants navigate between
sensory transposition, contrast based reasoning, literal correspondence,
and visual prominence in order to construct meaningful associations
between symptoms and physical variables. Their approaches highlight the
richness and complexity of symptom identification within the
participatory **environment** and reveal how material engagement fosters
interpret**ation**.

children.name: Overlaps, mismatches, and uncertainty in variable association
children.content:
Participants encountered several challenges when interpreting and
applying the variables during the workshop activities. One recurring
difficulty concerned uncertainty around the meaning of particular terms.
Some participants explicitly asked for clarification, demonstrating that
not all variable labels were immediately self-explanatory. For instance,
the meaning of “three dimensional form” was questioned (P9, WS2), and
similar confusion arose regarding “fuzziness”. These moments highlight
the need for clearer terminology and the value of providing contextual
examples to support shared understanding.

Another source of complexity stemmed from the overlapping interpretation
of values across different variables. Participants occasionally
associated a single descriptive element with multiple categories. One
participant observed that both “a lot of balls” and “a lot of big ones”
could correspond to quantity (P5, WS1), revealing how features such as
size, number, or repetition might relate simultaneously to amount,
density, or scale. In a similar way, colour was sometimes treated not as
a standalone dimension but as a cue for another quality, such as
temperature, with blue evoking a sensation of cold (P17, WS3).

These examples show that variable values often operate fluidly across
conceptual boundaries, making interpretation and representation less
straightforward. Such ambiguity required participants to reason through
their own associations when selecting variables, thereby adding an
additional layer of cognitive work to the activity. The presence of
these overlaps and mismatches indicates the importance of refining the
structure of the activity, ensuring clearer boundaries between variables
while preserving the openness that supports creative and embodied
interpretation.

children.name: Introduction
children.content: Materials play a central role in this research, both as expressive elements within the workshop activity and as analytical objects in the interpretation of results. Because the meaning of each artefact emerges through its material composition, visual documentation becomes essential for understanding how symptoms are translated into form. Photographs of the data-probes make visible the relationships between symptoms, variables, and material choices, allowing the analytical process to extend beyond textual accounts. To support this examination, the artefacts were reorganised into a series of visualisations that serve as analytical instruments rather than final outcomes. These visual supports help identify patterns, contrasts, and recurring strategies in how participants used physical components to externalise their experiences. The first visualisation (Fig. 14) highlights the role of materials in representing symptoms. Each data-probe is decomposed into its constituent parts, and the elements selected by participants to express particular conditions are reorganised according to the symptom they were meant to represent. The second visualisation (Fig. 15) reorders the artefacts according to their physical components rather than their assigned meanings. Foam, polystyrene, and wood appear in the form of spheres, triangular prisms, and cubes, grouped by material type and by size. Cases in which meaning was assigned to aggregated units are also included. Connectors, identified during analysis as central to the expressive process, are placed in the bottom left. Metal pieces and sandpaper appear in the bottom right, reflecting the raw material palette of the first workshop session before the final selection of components for later kits.

children.name: Personal experience, exclusion, and transposition as methods of selection
children.content:
Participants employed a wide range of strategies when selecting
materials for their artefacts, often guided by personal associations
linked to the symptom they aimed to represent. Material choices were
rarely based on formal qualities alone. Instead, they were shaped by
affective memories, sensory resonance, and embodied interpretation. One
participant expressed this directly: “I hate this kind of material,”
referring to polyester, which she selected precisely because it
triggered a negative physical memory and therefore reinforced the
unpleasantness of her symptom (P18, WS3). Another chose foam “because it
is an absorbent material,” associating its softness and capacity to hold
liquid with the sensation of incontinence (P4, WS1). These examples
illustrate a form of direct translation in which material properties
serve as proxies for bodily states.

Metaphorical reasoning also guided the use of sharpness, texture, and
weight. One participant associated the pain of urination with “something
sharp and very rough” moving through the body and constructed a mobile
artefact to capture that sensation (P7, WS1). Another highlighted
solidity by saying, “You feel something solid passing through you” (P4,
WS1), demonstrating how tactile responses were intentionally used to
simulate internal pain through physical form.

Several participants relied on exclusion as a method of selection. They
rejected specific shapes or materials when these conflicted with the
sensations they wished to express. One remarked, “Triangles and no…
balls” (G8, WS5), favouring angular forms that better communicated pain.
Another explained, “I’m trying to avoid any sphere. I feel like when
it’s smooth surface, it doesn’t quite explain the pain” (P9, WS2). Wood
was also dismissed for its comforting connotations: “I didn’t add wood
here because for me, wood is something cozy” (P18, WS3). These cases
highlight how avoidance can be as meaningful as selection, allowing
participants to refine their representations through contrast.

Colour, whether physically present or imagined, also influenced material
choices. One participant associated lighter shades with calm or peaceful
states and therefore rejected them, noting, “So I would prefer something
darker, or gray, or black” (General). Even when the materials did not
include specific colours, participants verbalised what they would have
chosen, indicating the expressive power of chromatic associations for
conveying emotional tone.

Transposition represented another common strategy, in which symptoms
were projected onto the material through reenactment or analogy. One
participant wrapped foam with rope to represent internal pressure and
residual urine: “this sort of chain around… creates these bubbles that
become sore” (P4, WS1). Another linked the brightness and shape of white
material to images of leakage and discomfort (P6, WS1). A participant
from another session twisted material to reflect joint pain during the
flu, referring to it as a “twisted knee” (G1, WS5).

Overall, participants choose, exclude, or transform materials based on
affective resonance, sensory analogy, and embodied knowledge. Whether
through metaphor, rejection, or transposition, materials become active
mediators of narrative, allowing participants to articulate the lived
experience of illness in expressive, multidimensional ways.

children.name: Materials as gesture elicitators
children.content:
Participants often used physical gestures not only as construction
techniques but as expressive actions intended to embody their symptom
experiences. These actions, such as pressing, pushing, destroying, or
even (ideally) burning the material, played a central role in
externalising discomfort. One participant proposed that “you could set
fire” to the material, using the imagined act of burning as a way to
evoke the sensory association of a bad smell. This symbolic gesture
expanded the meaning of the artefact beyond its visible qualities (P5,
WS1).

Another participant intentionally designed her artefact to be unstable.
During her presentation, she narrated, “and then also like unstable
because if you touch it will… no… boy come on,” before nudging the
object and allowing it to fall, concluding with “Yeah, it destroys”
(P18, WS3). The performative collapse became a metaphor for the body’s
fragility under illness. Similarly, one participant selected polyester
because “it's something that you can destroy with your hand. So it's
kind of something that you could spread, but it’s not going away,”
linking the material’s partial destructibility to the recurring and
persistent nature of cystitis (P11, WS2).

Even when gestures were not enacted, the impulse to manipulate or damage
materials remained noticeable. One participant admitted, “I wanted to
press your materials together. Okay. I hesitated because I thought I
cannot mess up your kit” (G8, WS5). This hesitation suggests that the
instinct to deform, compress, or otherwise act upon materials functioned
as an expressive drive, even when suppressed out of respect for the
toolkit.

These contributions indicate that action upon the material served as a
fundamental semiotic resource. Through gesture, manipulation, and
transformation, participants expressed the unpredictability, recurrence,
and emotional intensity of illness in ways that extended beyond static
representation.

children.name: Materials evoking secondary perceptions
children.content:
Some participants selected materials based on their ability to elicit
sensory responses beyond visual or tactile qualities, drawing on smell,
sound, and thermal associations to intensify the representation of
symptoms. Smell emerged as one of the most prominent dimensions. One
participant expressed the need for materials capable of reproducing
unpleasant odours, saying, “I want something for the stench” (P4, WS1).
To address this, she used glue, noting, “I take a vinavil thingy, which
stinks,” intentionally leveraging its odour as part of the expressive
vocabulary (P4, WS1). She later reinforced this preference by adding,
“Perfect. Plastic. Rubber,” confirming her deliberate use of materials
chosen for their particular scent (P4, WS1). Another participant
proposed using a permanent marker, asking, “Use a single-point marker,
do we have one? But some people like it,” recognising that even strong
chemical smells can carry expressive potential, despite differing
personal preferences (P5, WS1).

Auditory responses also played a role in how participants interpreted
and selected materials. One participant observed that “when
\[polyester\] touched to each other it makes a noise which like make a
painful inside,” linking the abrasive sound of the material to an
internal sensation of discomfort (P18, WS3). This association
demonstrates how sound was mobilised as a metaphorical extension of
physical pain, enabling multisensory expression within the artefact.

Temperature and weight, though less immediately perceptible, were
likewise used to express bodily conditions. One participant asked, “a
heavy material \[to represent fever\]? A material that makes, that gives
heat,” explicitly connecting mass and perceived warmth to the sensation
of fever (P4, WS1). This choice illustrates how thermal associations,
even when indirectly represented, contributed to conveying states of
overheating or internal pressure.

Overall, these examples show how participants relied on smell, sound,
and thermal associations **as** secondary perceptions to enhance the
expressive accuracy of their artefacts. By engaging multiple senses,
participants expanded the representational scope of the materials and
strengthened the emotional and experiential resonance of their
interpretations.

children.name: Plugs to connect components, and concepts
children.content:
Connectors played a critical role in the construction of the artefacts,
serving not only as structural elements but also as expressive
components that supported narrative and symbolic meaning. Initially
introduced to simplify the assembly process, connectors quickly became
central to how participants articulated relationships between parts of
their artefacts and, by extension, between different aspects of their
symptoms. One participant noted the need “for a connection from two
different sides,” explaining that a more flexible connector was required
“to connect different situations” (P10, WS2). This reflects how
connectors were not just tools for mechanical aggregation but were also
used to build conceptual or temporal bridges within the representation
of illness.

Several participants emphasised the expressive value of connectors. One
participant stated, “I think the connecting material were important. In
case to even express, yeah. The pain” (G8, WS5), suggesting that the act
of linking materials could itself convey symptom intensity or
interaction. Another added that the meaning of her artefact became clear
only during the process of connection: “That became only clear to us
when we connected it, and then we’re like, oh my God… these tubes are
really cool” (G8, WS5). Here, connectors functioned not only to complete
the artefact’s form but to reveal latent meaning through spatial and
symbolic alignment.

The technical qualities of the connectors were also subject to critique.
Some participants found them too short or rigid to accommodate the
complexity of their ideas. One participant remarked, “Maybe (the
connector) longer… so I can decide how long it is” (P3, WS1), while
another expressed dissatisfaction with the material: “I missed longer
connectors… I wasn’t happy with the material to be honest with you” (P3,
WS1). These reflections suggest that connectors constrained design
choices when insufficient in length or adaptability. Others simply
requested more of them, highlighting their importance to the overall
process: “Maybe something more connections” (G1, WS4). Overall,
connectors operated on multiple levels: functionally, they enabled the
construction of stable and articulated forms; conceptually, they allowed
participants to express relational or causal dynamics between symptoms;
and materially, they became symbolic elements in their own right. Their
success or failure to perform these roles had a visible impact on both
the visual outcomes and the interpretative clarity of the artefacts.

These approaches show that participants did not only build to show what
illness looks like, but to communicate how it feels, moves, and limits.
The visual strategies employed ranged from playful figuration to stark
metaphor, reflecting diverse understandings of illness and different
ways of translating it into form.

children.name: Glass and plasticine among the missing materials
children.content:
Participants identified a wide range of materials they considered
missing from the kit, revealing both practical needs for construction
and symbolic gaps in symptom expression. One recurring category
concerned sharp or fragile materials. Glass was mentioned several times,
valued not for its transparency but for its fragility and cutting
quality. As one participant noted, “That is why I wouldn't use the wood,
but I will probably use the glass because it's something sharp” (P18,
WS3). The absence of glass was perceived as a limitation, with the same
participant emphasising, “One part is missing. It's a piece of glass
because it's something sharp” (P18, WS3). Metal was similarly requested,
particularly for its weight and tactile resistance. “It’s heavy also and
that’s what I needed,” explained a participant, who associated heaviness
with sensations such as pressure or discomfort (P17, WS3). Others added
that metal could effectively represent pain due to its density and
hardness (P14, WS2). Metal wire was also mentioned as desirable for its
shaping and connecting possibilities (P4, WS1).

Participants frequently pointed out the absence of mouldable materials,
such as Play Doh, clay, or plasticine. These substances were appreciated
for their familiarity, flexibility, and low threshold for engagement.
One participant suggested, “Play Doh might be very interesting because
it’s something very moldable,” highlighting its potential for creating
diverse or irregular forms (P14, WS2). Another clarified that “it
doesn't have to be sculpture or not sort of designers do it, but
something that can again show the different symptoms” (P14, WS2). The
capacity to represent transformation, complexity, or fluidity made such
materials particularly appealing.

Colour also emerged as a critical missing component. Since the original
kit consisted entirely of neutral tones, several participants felt
constrained by the lack of chromatic expression. “These neutral colours
don’t describe like the pain for me,” one explained, adding that red or
flesh-like tones would have been more appropriate (P20, WS3). Another
stated, “I would need colours! Yellow...” (P2, WS1), while a third
emphasised, “For me, the colours were very important” (P14, WS2).
Participants also linked colour to temperature and mood, with one noting
that “brighter colours could have probably meant something for people as
well” (P14, WS2). Although some appreciated the focus enabled by a
neutral palette, colour clearly represented a missing expressive layer.

Requests also extended to structural forms and supports. A flatter base
was needed in one case: “It would be better if it was a cube but not a
cube but a parallelogram, so flatter” (P17). Others proposed 3D printing
as a way to overcome shape limitations. Preferences for specific
textures were also evident. Foam spheres, for example, were criticised
for being too rigid compared to foam cubes and prisms: “The foam sphere
is not made of the same material as the other foam components,” a
participant observed, noting that this inconsistency influenced
representational coherence (G2, WS4). Participants also expressed
interest in rubbery textures that could simulate skin or muscle, with
one suggesting, “Maybe like a rubbery… if it was like proper flexible
rubber” (G1, WS4). Textiles were requested for their ability to simulate
thin bodily layers: “Either textiles and scissors to have something,
because I was related to the body, the very thin layers” (General).

In addition to these more symbolic materials, common building aids were
also requested: pins (P4, P6, WS1), toothpicks (P2, WS1), twine (P4,
WS1), and scissors (General). These items would have supported both the
construction of more elaborate structures and the expressive richness of
the artefacts.

Taken together, these requests demonstrate that the missing materials
were not simply logistical gaps. They reflected the ways participants
actively sought tools to extend their symbolic vocabulary and engage
more deeply with the physical expression of symptoms. These observations
offer concrete guidance for refining future iterations of the material
kit and ensuring that material choices fully support embodied
representation and narrative expression.

children.name: Sharpness and amorphousness: the missing features
children.content:
In addition to requesting new materials, participants identified
limitations in the qualities of the materials that were already
available. These missing features concerned not the substance of the kit
but the absence of specific properties such as sharpness, amorphousness,
texture, and flexibility, which were needed to fulfil expressive
intentions or support construction.

One of the most frequently mentioned gaps related to sharpness.
Participants noted that the existing components were not sufficiently
edgy or spiky to represent sensations such as stabbing, cutting, or
burning. As one remarked, “I thought I should have something that's more
spiky than what was available” (G7, WS5). Another added, “They’re not
representative of the pain that I have here” (G8, WS5). These
observations underline the need for components with sharper geometries
to convey acute discomfort in physical form.

At the same time, participants expressed the opposite need for materials
that could capture organic or irregular forms. One participant
explained, “I wanted to change this to more like organic shape and
rather than something rigid with sharp edges” (P20, WS3). Another
emphasised the desire for “something more amorphous, like a clay or
something, that I can give a shape to” (G8, WS5). These comments
indicate that geometric and regular shapes were often too limited to
represent fluid, diffused, or irregular sensations.

Textural qualities were also a source of concern. Some participants
wished for materials with a more fluid texture: “I was hoping for fluid
texture” (P16, WS3). Others asked for elasticity or rubberiness, as in
the request that “a rubbery material will be nice” (G1, WS4). These
preferences suggest that flexibility and stretch are important symbolic
dimensions for representing sensations such as tension, fullness, or
internal movement. Inconsistencies within the existing kit further
contributed to this issue. One participant observed that the foam sphere
was harder than the other foam components, which interfered with
representational consistency (G2, WS4).

Transparency was also identified as a missing feature. One participant
referred to the absence of “material that is completely… not
transparent” (P11, WS2), suggesting that this property could symbolise
clarity, visibility, or transformation depending on context.

Participants additionally asked for small, functional tools to support
construction, such as paper clips (G3, WS5), toothpicks, scissors, and
rubber bands. Although not materials in themselves, these basic tools
were needed to stabilise artefacts, extend expressive possibilities, and
support more complex shaping.

The analysis highlights that the limitations of the kit were not only
material but also qualitative. Missing features affected how
participants could manipulate form, gesture, and structure to construct
meaning. While missing materials reveal gaps in the substance of the
kit, missing features point to constraints in its expressive
flexibility. Both sets of concerns offer valuable guidance for future
refinement of the material system, suggesting the importance of a more
diverse, adaptable, and responsive palette to support embodied
interpretation in participatory settings.

children.name: Lack of cohesion
children.content:
Participants encountered a range of difficulties while interacting with
the material kit, particularly during the construction phase. Several
comments pointed to physical limitations in the properties of the units.
One participant explained that “its shapes does not work, so I took
something heavy that's on top,” indicating that the shape alone was
insufficient to convey the intended meaning and required compensation
through added weight (P17, WS3). Another expressed uncertainty about the
structural integrity of her artefact, stating, “mine will never hold,”
and later adding, “I made this… it was to hold together but they don't
hold,” illustrating how fragility and instability hindered her ability
to build a coherent form (P6, WS1).

Difficulties combining units were a recurring issue. One participant
noted, “I was needed to connect this two pieces but it was difficult,”
referring to mechanical challenges in linking components (P10, WS2).
Glue was also problematic; participants reported long drying times (“you
have to wait for all the scaffolding to dry,” P4, WS2) and lack of
adhesion, especially with metal spheres (“it is a nightmare to glue the
balls, they do not fit,” P4, WS1). These obstacles often forced
participants to intervene manually to ensure stability, interrupting the
flow of the activity and limiting expressive freedom.

Thermal properties introduced another layer of complexity. One
participant observed that “some \[units\] are cold and some others are
not,” suggesting that the variable temperature of the materials
influenced how they were matched to symptoms (P12, WS2). These
differences affected the emotional and sensory associations participants
sought to express through material choice.

Conceptual challenges also emerged. A participant reflected on the
cultural specificity of symbolic cues, particularly colour, noting that
“in our society or country, but not, they are not universal” (WS5). This
remark highlighted the risk of miscommunication when symbolic
associations are not shared among participants from different
backgrounds.

Further confusion arose from difficulty identifying materials.
Participants struggled to name or classify components, asking, “How do
we call? Is this and foam, foam plastic, you know?” (P17, WS3) or
simply, “This is foam?” (P13, WS2). Others referred to it informally as
“spongy thing” (P11, WS2), “SpongeBob” (participant), or “memory foam”
(P20, WS3). These inconsistencies, though minor, generated hesitation
and uncertainty when selecting materials and articulating their intended
meaning.

These challenges appear multifaceted, involving structural limitations,
unfamiliarity with certain materials, mismatches between intended and
available features, and various forms of symbolic ambiguity. Although
the kit is designed to support expressive engagement, these barriers at
times reduced the ease with which participants could construct coherent
and meaningful representations. They also prompted reflection on what
additional elements might have been beneficial and on the point at which
the available materials can be considered sufficient for the activity.

children.name: Just enough to reveal what is missing
children.content:
Participant feedback on the material kit revealed a mix of appreciation
and critique, showing how even a limited set of tools can provoke both
creative engagement and moments of frustration. Several participants
offered positive observations, highlighting aspects of the kit that
supported their process. One participant valued the neutral colour
palette, stating, “I really enjoyed that it was neutral. Yeah, exactly.
It was not distracting.” The absence of strong colours was perceived as
enabling focus rather than diverting attention away from the task.

This view was reinforced by another participant, who noted that the
materials on hand, although limited, actually helped clarify what was
missing: “What was available was helping to form this… to form this idea
what it should look like” (G7, WS5). Here, constraint encouraged
reflection, prompting participants to imagine alternatives and refine
their interpretive strategies.

Some participants also expressed satisfaction with the geometric forms
provided. As one stated, “I think the shapes are good… I didn’t think of
like, oh, I need another shape” (G1, WS4). Although this participant
later suggested adding rubbery materials to enhance texture, the core
set of shapes was considered sufficient for constructing meaningful
artefacts.

At the same time, several concerns emerged regarding quantity and
expressive range. Material scarcity was a recurring issue. One
participant remarked, “I was running out of material, to be honest” (P3,
WS1), indicating that the limited number of units constrained the
construction of more complex forms. Others commented on the expressive
limitations of the kit. One participant noted, “I really missed some
more expressive materials, to be fair” (G8, WS5), while another pointed
out that the materials felt “a little bit lighter, neutral, compared
with pain when peeing” (P18, WS3). This mismatch between the emotional
intensity of symptoms and the polished, generic appearance of the
materials was felt throughout the sessions.

In one case, a participant deliberately selected a slightly damaged
sphere because its imperfect condition aligned with the sensation she
wished to express. She explained, “It was kind of already, like, marred…
so this is what I feel my shoulder is coming in stages, to be fair” (G8,
WS5). This comment implicitly critiques the overly pristine, idealised
quality of the rest of the kit.

These responses show that while the kit was broadly appreciated for its
neutrality, clarity, and simplicity, participants also perceived its
limitations in terms of variety, tactile intensity, and visual nuance.
These tensions highlight a core challenge in designing for open-ended
expression which corresponds to providing a material palette that is
limited enough to be manageable but diverse enough to support rich and
embodied representation.

children.name: Theme 3: Symptom-physical variable associations
children.content: The associations between symptoms and material components reveal a situated and materially grounded process of representation. Participants relied not only on the physical properties of the available units but also on their embodied experiences to construct meaning. Pain, particularly in relation to urinary tract symptoms, was consistently represented through rough textures, sharp edges, and heavy materials. Triangular prisms, wood, and metal elements were often selected for this purpose, supported by verbal reflections such as “associated with angles… sharp or tuned” (P18, WS3). When expressing discomfort during urination, participants frequently manipulated polyester units to produce friction and sound, transforming tactile gestures into representations of internal irritation. Ambiguous sensations, described as blurriness or uncertainty, were conveyed through opaque or visually diffuse materials, reflecting the difficulty of understanding a symptom while still perceiving its presence (P18, WS3). Colour also played an important role in anchoring certain symptoms. Yellow was selected to signify cystitis, while red was used to represent blood in urine, demonstrating how visual cues contributed to diagnostic clarity. Psychological symptoms were sometimes represented through composite or unstable structures. Participants created asymmetrical or precarious arrangements to evoke feelings of anxiety, imbalance, or mental strain. Temporal aspects of the illness were also explored. Symptoms such as urgency and incontinence were represented using rolling spheres or compressed spatial configurations to suggest speed, frequency, or loss of control. The table below summarises all associations cited across the workshop sessions. Each association is further described in the text, along with participants’ motivations. These explanations provide crucial insight into how meaning was constructed during the activity and how material choices acquired expressive and interpretative value. - **The difficulties of the disease** are associated with the variable of weight and more specifically the value of heaviness, represented by wood.  - The general **pain** is associated with:  - Texture (“suffering is rough”); - Sharpness made of edges and spikes recurrent in the triangular prisms. These pointy peaks not only symbolise the severity of pain but also contribute to creating an irregular, rough surface. This reinforces the earlier association of pain with roughness, merging the sharpness and irregularity into a cohesive representation of the symptom;   - Temperature (warmness/high temperature); - Weight (heaviness).  - The **increasing pain** is associated with elasticity referring to the ability to stretch. Rather than simply representing pain, one participant suggested using the material to exemplify how her body feels when affected by the disease. She imagines her body stretched, expanding in size and volume. She also emphasises, “i*t's not something that's just like transparent or like something that you can go through it*” (P20), combining the sensation of pain with the idea of bigger bodies that resist and contrast.  - The **worsening of the conditions** is associated with:  - Weight (heaviness) and represented by wood; - Sharpness and the edges of the triangular shapes. To increase the peaks, edges are also adopted, even if originally available to combine the units together.  - The red colour represented by sandpaper, which was available only during the first workshop session in its default red colour.  - **Aching**, which is continuous and unpleasant but not very strong, is represented by the sphere: “*The first symptoms that I usually have are these ones, so discomfort and pain when peeing, and I represent them with a sphere because I see the sphere or something that is still. Since it doesn't have so many edges, so I think like something that is still feasible to manage.*” Edges are perceived as difficulties and are associated with pain. The more the edges the more the pain. Because of this reason, the sphere is chosen to represent initial symptoms or the discomfort generated by the disease (P5). Sphere as sign of discomfort because no edges involved, pointing to a general situation which can improve instead of getting worse.  - **Lighter symptoms** are associated with weight (lightness) and represented by polyester.  - The **general symptoms** of cystitis are represented by yellow and represented colouring with acrylics some units related to the pain caused by urinating.  - **Discomfort when urinating** is associated with blurriness, “*you feel something but you don't understand what is that.*” (P18).  - The imaginary friction caused by the **discomfort and pain when urinating** has been transformed into an active gesture performed on polyester to produce sound, and noise more specifically. The pain when urinating is associated with friction that is transformed into a gesture that produces noise. This association is not straightforward, but the variable is selected through different steps that involve senses differently. The sound produced by the units of polyester is also recognised as similarly irritating, reinforcing the association of this material with discomfort.  - The **pain during urination** is associated with sharpness, represented by the edges of polyester units. Triangular shapes of polyester are identified as symbolic of this sort of pain. One of the participants clearly stated this association: “*It's when usually the doctor asks me what kind of pain you have. It's usually like associated with angles. It might be sharp or tuned*” (P18).  - The **burning sensation experienced during urination** is associated with:  - Roughness (a value referring to the surface texture identified by Hornecker and colleagues in their classification) and represented by metal wire pins pierced around a polyester unit. The participant assembled the material while imagining the object moving through her body, evoking the same intense pain caused by the disease.  - Temperature.  - **Swollen bladder and kidney** are associated with the variable of friction and represented by small cubes in foam considered “*rubbery and stretchy*” by the participant. This representation is linked to the idea of organs and body parts that increase in size and volume when affected by the disease.   - The **pain behind the bladder** is associated with roughness and represented by small spheres and pins of metal embedded in a unit of polyester.  - The **inability to fully empty the bladder** is associated with pattern and texture. While no further explanation was provided for this association, it may be conceptually linked to the earlier association with roughness.  - The **swollen stomach** is round and regular. (How much do the words to describe the symptoms influence the perception and the representation of the symptom itself? “Swollen”).  - The **need to urinate and incontinence** are associated with:  - The variable of time due to their urgency, frequency, and duration. Urgency compresses the time to act, while frequent episodes emphasise recurrence. Incontinence varies from brief to prolonged, disrupting daily routines and creating temporal distress, making time central to understanding and representing these symptoms. Timing is represented by a big wooden sphere because of the inertia of the rounded shape which naturally tend to roll and move.  - Pressure, because of the physical perception and urgency.  - Permeability, and represented by foam which has been considered, compared to the other materials available, the one that can keep the liquids the most.  - Boundness. To recreate this feeling, the rope was wrapped tightly around a unit of foam, creating some growth standing for the urine constipated in the body.  - The presence of **blood in the urine** is associated with:  - Brightness, primarily due to its visual representation. This association provided an opportunity for a participant to introduce an important diagnostic insight, emphasizing the distinction between menstrual blood and the blood associated with cystitis. This differentiation, previously mentioned during the discussion of symptoms, highlights the diagnostic relevance of colour and brightness in understanding the condition.  - Red colour. Participants recognised colour, particularly red, as one of the most significant visual variables, confirming its suitability for symbolising blood. In healthcare, blood is universally regarded as an indicator of urgency, and this urgency is mirrored in the prominence of the colour variable within visual representations. The use of red effectively conveys the critical nature of this symptom, aligning with its diagnostic and communicative importance.   - The **cloudy urine** is associated with opacity, based on the same interpretative principle.  - **Fever** was initially associated with the variable of temperature and represented by wood, reflecting the perception of warmness commonly linked to this material.  - Some participants recognise this association as literal and for this reason try to move forward suggesting alternative associations. In one case, to represent different temperatures, and warm temperatures specific to fever, participants suggest working on the nature of the material instead of their direct degree surface, such as fur and wool. This idea opens to different methods of representing the same variable, instead of changing the variable to represent that specific symptom.  - **Nausea** is associated with:  - Brightness.  - Lightness, and represented by small polyester spheres.  - The concept of floating and suspension, linking it to the variable of position. This interpretation considers not only the location of individual units but also their relationship to one another, emphasising the interconnected dynamics that contribute to the sensation.  - **Vomiting** is associated with:  - Shape, size, quantity, and frequency of material units, represented by small wooden spheres. These units symbolise the symptom's recurrence, typically observed during the worsening of an infection. Their selection allowed the expert to highlight the diagnostic significance of quantity and frequency, as these details provide critical insights into the patient's condition. The variable of amount not only visually conveys rhythm but also introduces a sound component, further enriching the representation of vomiting.  - Brightness, symbolising a clear and unmistakable sign that something is wrong. Unlike the previous approach, which leans toward a literal representation of the symptom, this association situates vomiting within the broader context of the disease. Here, it is used as a lens to interpret and understand the overall condition rather than focusing solely on the symptom itself.  - **Tiredness** is associated with:  - Colour gradient, which might be considered a value that combines the variable of hue, saturation or brightness.  - Body mass and density, represented by wood. The unit is described by the participant as “full”.   - The **need to lie down** when sick, which is not a symptom, but a behaviour driven by the disease, is associated with orientation and is represented by the artefact extending horizontally.  - **Inability** to move and restricted flexibility are associated with rigidity and associated with short connectors between units of material.  - **Recurrency** is associated with:  - Amount and represented by several composition. Each composition stands for one of the episodes that the participant attributes to one proper event of illness.  - Endurance and spreading of polyester, which crumbles yet remains difficult to eliminate, representing the persistent and challenging nature of eradicating the infection.  - Spatial disposition is represented through a linear arrangement, symbolised by the rope. This also allow participants to correlated causes and effects of the disease. One participant makes sure that the rope can close suggesting the repetitiveness of the episodes.  - The **complexity** of the disease, due to many aspects and factors involved, is associated with:  - Texture, created with metal pins crossing each other in a sort of net woven on a polyester unit.  - Multitude and variety of materials used. Each material represents a distinct facet of the condition. Rather than establishing a one-to-one correlation between symptoms and the variable, the overall experience is expressed through the perception of contrasts and differences that emerge when comparing the various physical elements. This approach represents a different method of association and interpretation compared to the more direct ones discussed earlier. In this case, a broader perspective takes precedence over detailed analysis, allowing the meaning conveyed by the objects to emerge through an overarching view. Even though variety is not considered in this context as a proper variable as it can be breakdown by associating specific materials to punctual causes of the disease complexity.  - **Unusual health conditions** are associated with the spatial disposition of elements, represented through disorder or mess, reflecting the disruption caused by these conditions.  - **Psychological discomfort** is associated with:  - Roughness.   - Rigidity, and represented by wooden cubes.  - Dimensions and stability inversely related: the greater the discomfort, the larger the dimensions and the less stable the overall artefact. While most associations among symptoms, variables, and materials focus on individual material units, this participant took a holistic approach by referring directly to the final artefact. This allowed her to incorporate the concept of instability, which arises from how she selected and combined the individual units, into the representation of the symptom. To recreate this perception, bigger cubes have been mounted on top of smaller wooden cubes that serve as bases. In a different occasion, the same result is perceived with small metal spheres.  - **Anxiety** caused by the disease, persisting in daily life even after treatment, is associated with:  - Weight (heaviness) and represented multiple metal spheres resting on a soft foam surface.  - Triangular shapes made in polyester.  - The **uncertainty** related to the next step of the disease (if improving or worsening) is associated with the physical instability of the units.  - An important step within the progress of the disease considers the **intervention of the doctor** which is associated with a turning point and represented by a knot on the rope.  - The **efficacy of the treatment**, reflected in the disappearance of symptoms, is associated with emptiness, represented by a segment of (empty) rope placed among other threaded units. In this case, the value is assigned to the absence of materiality. This association gains significance within the broader context of other symptoms being represented by tangible materials.  Associations that emerged during workshop sessions four and five, which focused on conditions other than UTIs, are also presented below. Although analysed separately, they are included here because they offer valuable insights into the broader ways in which participants use materials to represent embodied experiences. - The itchy throat is associated with friction (G1, WS5).  - Throat ache and swallowing are represented by a linear transparent connector with some metal wire inside (G3, WS5). The wire is "*something moving. Yeah, something disrupting the throat. Mm hmm. It's making one cough*” (G3, WS5). In this case, the association is possible by comparison. The wire would not have the same meaning if not passing through the flexible and transparent connector.  - Linearity is also used to symbolising the progression of the tonsillitis and transparent elements are incorporated to reflect fluidity (G3, WS5.  - The loss of voice is associated with sound enveloping (G1, WS4).  - The knee-joint pain is associated with kinesthetic friction and represented by a small wooden cube positioned opposite to larger cubes at the base and top. “This is like a twisted knee” (G1, WS4). This representation is part of a composition intentionally compared to the shape of a human figure. The cubes symbolise the legs, even though the structure consists of a single stack rather than a pair, as might typically represent human legs.  - Constipation is associated with compactness. The cube in wood is selected because of the density of the material that reminds the fullness caused by the difficulty in emptying the bowels (G1, WS4).  - The feeling of fullness caused by food in the case of lactose intolerance is similarly represented by the density of the material and the angles of the shape (G2, WS4).  - Bloating (following the constipation) is represented by a sphere (G2, WS4).  - Stomach-ache is associated with compression and represented by a “*squishy triangle*” of foam (G4, WS5).  - The nausea is a small wooden sphere which participants refers to as “marble” moving inside the body (G2, WS4).  - The lower back pain is associated with the sharpness and the triangular prism (G2, WS4).  - Neck pain is associated with spikiness and the possibility/impossibility of moving represented by triangular prisms (G7, WS5). The fact that this condition is not always present is depicted by the multiplicity of materials, for this purpose, wood, polyester, and foam were adopted.  - For opposition, the ideal condition of the shoulder is associated with softness and represented by foam.  - Mental fog is differently represented with small polyester spheres (G2, WS4).  - Fatigue is associated with sound enveloping and blurriness.  - Insomnia is embodied in a sense of constant motion and restlessness represented by a flexible connector that should have been longer, as from the participant’s request, not to stop like this condition.  - The worsening of the conditions with weight and size and for this reason represented by wood (G2, WS4).  - Feeling overwhelmed is associated with being surrounded and recreated positioning one small sphere at the centre of triangular prisms recreating a square.

children.name: Artefact structures between abstraction and figuration
children.content:
Participants adopted a wide range of visual, spatial, and material
strategies to externalise their experience of UTIs. These strategies
move between abstraction and figuration, integrating metaphor,
symbolism, and aesthetics to communicate symptoms, emotions, and broader
illness narratives. One of the most recurrent approaches involved
structuring the illness as a linear process. Several artefacts took the
form of timelines or journeys, in which participants arranged components
to express the recurrence of discomfort, the progression of symptoms, or
the cyclic nature of the condition (P2, P5, P11, P15 – WS1, 2, 3). These
linear constructions also conveyed emotional states such as anxiety or
uncertainty at critical turning points, visually expressing the
illness’s fluctuating trajectory (P3, P5 – WS1).

Alongside these temporal representations, many participants embraced
figuration, building recognisable or suggestive shapes. Some constructed
house-like forms, as in the case of a participant who announced, “I am
making a beautiful house. A tree house” (P19, WS3), or another who
recognised in a peer’s structure, “Oh cute, it looks like a house” (P18,
WS3). Others leaned into more metaphorical interpretations: “It’s like a
boat” (P15, WS3), or “a cherry on the top of my cake… to make it more
unstable” (P18), adding layers of associative meaning to otherwise
abstract compositions. In more anthropomorphic forms, artefacts were
shaped to resemble the human body to facilitate symptom localisation,
sometimes evoking imagery such as a voodoo doll (P1, P6 – WS1).

This supported a relational mapping of pain across body parts, allowing
for embodied storytelling.

Aesthetic considerations were also central. Participants used materials
to evoke emotional textures or subjective discomforts. One explicitly
stated, “I’m trying to build something disgusting” (P18), selecting
elements that visually communicated fragility or repulsion. The final
artefact, described as “pathetic and weak… made with disgusting
materials” (P18, WS3), visualised vulnerability through deliberate
material choices. By contrast, another participant rejected an artefact
for being “too cozy,” arguing that its polished wooden form was
misaligned with the painful experience it was meant to express (P18,
WS3). This aesthetic mismatch, where beauty or softness undermined the
communicative intent, which was also noted by another participant who
preferred “rough textures” over those that appeared “too cute” (P15,
WS3).

Several participants adopted a more intuitive process, shaping without a
predetermined concept. “I would say first created and then I thought
about what it could be,” explained one participant (P2, WS1),
highlighting how meaning emerged through material engagement rather than
conceptual planning. This process-oriented method often allowed metaphor
to surface retroactively, shaped by the properties of the materials and
the associations they triggered.

Multiplicity and fragmentation also played key roles in how participants
structured their artefacts. Some chose to construct modular,
discontinuous forms, using separated elements to reflect episodic
flare-ups or instability (P3, P9, P14 – WS1, 2). Different materials
were often used to represent emotional contrasts or symptom variation,
such as soft foams for transience, harsh textures for pain, metal for
stiffness. In several cases, empty spaces or voids indicated phases of
remission or the absence of symptoms, such as the effect of antibiotics
(P5, WS1).

children.name: Generative metaphors for narrations
children.content:
Metaphors emerged as a powerful mechanism for expressing complex,
subjective experiences of illness through tangible form. Rather than
functioning merely as illustrative language, they acted as
interpretative method enabling participants to bridge the gap between
bodily sensation and physical representation.

Painful urination, for instance, was not simply described but
externalised through expressions like “fire drops” (P2, WS1), “wood
chips” (P6, WS1), and “hot pins stuck in the urethra” (P2, WS1). These
vivid formulations anchored abstract discomforts in specific physical
images, directly informing the choice of sharp, rough, or pointed
materials. The difficulty in urinating was metaphorically framed as “a
spiky object covered in metal pins passing through the body,” a
conceptualisation that later guided the construction of a material
artefact featuring embedded metal elements (P4, WS1).

Beyond isolated symptoms, some metaphors reflected broader narratives.
One participant described her artefact as “something disgusting” to
embody the repulsion caused by the disease (P18, WS3), while another
likened the illness to “a monster” (P5, WS4), projecting its emotional
impact onto the final object. These ontological metaphors provided
concrete identities to abstract conditions, helping participants
externalise what might otherwise remain internal and inexpressible.
Similarly, references to figurative shapes such as “a house” (P19, WS3),
“a boat” (P15, WS3), or “a doll” (G1, WS4) endowed the artefacts with
recognisable form, transforming symptom representations into objects
with character, place, or symbolic meaning.

Other metaphors served structural purposes, guiding the overall
organisation of the artefacts. The use of a linear configuration, for
instance, was described as “a flow... both temporal and metaphorical” of
urination (P2, WS1), or as a “journey” (P11, WS2), turning the artefact
into a narrative space. Connectors were described as “bridges” between
mild and severe states (P14, WS2), reflecting both the speed and
reversibility of symptom escalation. These structural metaphors shaped
not only the logic of the composition but also the sequencing and
physical linking of components.

Affective responses were equally central. One participant described
their construction as “pathetic and weak”, assembled with materials they
found “disgusting” (P18, WS3), while another disqualified a peer’s
artefact for looking “too cosy” to represent disease (P18, WS3). These
affective metaphors conveyed emotional resonance, translating feelings
such as discomfort, fragility, or denial into material and aesthetic
choices.

These metaphorical strategies show that participants use figurative
thinking to give shape to experiences that are difficult to describe
directly. In this sense, metaphors become practical tools that help them
understand and communicate their symptoms. Their frequent use in the
workshop highlights the importance of interpretative flexibility in
participatory data physicalization, enabling forms of expression that go
beyond what physical variables alone can represent.

children.name: Participants attitude towards the artefact
children.content:
Participants expressed a wide range of emotional responses regarding the
outcome of their artefacts, revealing how satisfaction was closely tied
to both material execution and emotional investment. Some participants
demonstrated a strong sense of care and attachment to their creations.
One described their artefact as “my beautiful, beautiful \[artefact\]”
(P1, WS1), while another expressed frustration when a structural element
failed, stating that a malfunction “ruined my whole structure” (P4,
WS1). These reactions suggest that the act of shaping was not merely
functional but deeply affective, with success or failure in execution
impacting personal satisfaction.

Conversely, some participants expressed disappointment or insecurity
about their results, particularly when the artefact did not physically
behave as intended. A lack of confidence in material stability (P6, WS1)
or an inability to balance the structure due to limited technical
knowledge (P16, WS3) led to visible dissatisfaction. Despite these
challenges, several participants described the experience in positive
and emotionally resonant terms. One participant described the
transformation of symptoms into shapes as “very poetic” (P16, WS3),
while others responded with spontaneous expressions of delight,
referring to the artefacts as “cute” or evoking nostalgic feelings of
childlike wonder (P17, P18 – WS3). These responses highlight how, beyond
technical outcomes, the participatory process generated affective
responses that blended pride, frustration, amusement, and emotional
reflection. Satisfaction was not solely dependent on the physical
success of the artefact, but also on the participant’s personal
engagement and the meanings embedded in the creative process.

children.name: Naming for positioning
children.content:
Participants occasionally reflected on how to name or categorise their
creations, highlighting how terminology shaped both the artefact and the
experience it conveyed. In one instance, a participant hesitated between
calling the outcome an “artefact” or an “installation,” expressing
uncertainty about its classification but also allowing room for multiple
interpretations (P18, WS3). In another case, a participant referred to
their piece as a “model,” explaining that it represented the presence of
symptoms within the body (P12, WS2). Some artefacts were referred to
more abstractly as a “thing,” pointing to a general sense of material
assemblage without specific classification. In more expressive terms,
one participant described their final object as a “monster,” revealing
how the artefact came to embody the disease itself through its form and
symbolic weight (P5, WS1). Similarly, another participant framed her
artefact as “something disgusting,” projecting the emotional discomfort
of the illness into the overall composition (P18, W3). In contrast, the
use of the term “doll” suggested identification with a human figure,
allowing symptoms to be mapped onto the body and transforming the object
into a visualised stand-in for personal experience (G1, WS4). Another
participant described the whole artefact as a “journey,” referring to
the linear arrangement of components as a metaphor for the illness’s
temporal unfolding (P11, WS2). These naming choices reveal how
participants navigated the ambiguity of their creations, adopting terms
that reflected symbolic, emotional, or functional interpretations.

children.name: Describing the representation
children.content:
Some participants engaged in describing or framing how their artefacts
should be read, often by clarifying what the representation was
intended, or not intended, to convey. P1 (WS1) specified that the iron
wire wrapped around a ball was not meant to suggest constraint, but
rather to indicate the complexity of each situation, which must be
considered individually. Similarly, the same participant used rough
paper to state that “the world is not smooth,” referring to the
inevitable presence of imperfections or interruptions (P1, WS1). In
other cases, artefacts were described as representing general symptoms,
such as the repeated experience of cystitis, where cloudy yellow acrylic
was used to evoke associations with urine (P2, WS1).

Some participants chose to depict normal or healthy bodily states to
create contrast with illness. Examples included describing softness as
an “ideal state” of the body (G8, WS5), arranging materials in
structured forms to express being “full of energy” (P2, WS1), and using
foam shapes to signify the absence of discomfort (P13, WS2). Others
designed artefacts that represented alternating or cyclical conditions,
such as the back-and-forth experience of a blocked and running nose (G1,
WS4).

Finally, one participant used handwritten notes to accompany and explain
the artefact during presentation (P11, WS2), demonstrating how verbal or
written annotations were incorporated to clarify meaning when material
forms alone were insufficient.

children.name: United by a common condition
children.content:
The participatory nature of the workshops played a central role in
facilitating interaction, exchange, and emotional engagement.
Participants often reflected on their symptoms in response to what
others shared, creating moments of comparison, confirmation, or
questioning. One participant remarked, “For me, I don't experience all
of this,” while reviewing symptom labels (P20, WS3), whereas another
asked, “Are these symptoms related only to UTIs or just general
symptoms?” (P20, WS3). These comments show how group dialogue encouraged
self-reflection and highlighted differences in experience. Others
confirmed alignment with the collective discussion: “Yes, an experience
of UTI. These seem correct” (P15, WS3). Some participants expressed
uncertainty about their own experiences, as in the admission, “I feel
like I’m the one that’s not normal” (P17, WS3).

Alongside these exchanges, participants also shared personal narratives
more openly. One asked, “Like according to my experience, can I share it
or not?” (P18), while another described writing down symptoms as
“relieving,” explaining that sharing them made the burden feel lighter
by realising others had experienced similar conditions. The group format
thus fostered a safe, responsive environment. Recruiting participants
based on shared experiences of illness enabled spontaneous conversation
and peer support, particularly around anxiety and the impact of UTIs on
daily life.

Working in groups also elicited detailed symptom descriptions, often
offered by participants directly to one another. In contrast, a one to
one format with a facilitator might not have produced equivalent detail,
as participants may have assumed shared understanding or omitted
explanations. In the workshop setting, expressions were more instinctive
and less shaped by expectations of correctness, and the experimental
character of the tasks encouraged spontaneous insights that might not
have emerged otherwise.

Language differences did not hinder communication. Instead, they
prompted participants to clarify meanings through paraphrasing,
examples, or collaborative interpretation. When unfamiliar with terms
such as groin or incontinence (P12, P17, P19 – WS2, 3), participants
actively worked together to resolve misunderstandings. This process not
only improved communication but also encouraged deeper reflection on
sensations and interpretations, generating rich, situated descriptions
of the illness.

Although the group setting generally supported interaction, there were
exceptions. Of the approximately thirty participants involved in the
final two workshops, only two (P25, P26, WS5) chose to work
independently. One ultimately did not present their work, likely due to
the private nature of the condition explored. The other reported that
aesthetic pleasure guided their design choices more than meaning. These
cases suggest that while group activities promote social exchange and
collective meaning-making, individual work may be more suitable for
deeply personal or sensitive content. This structure proves beneficial,
as it encourages mutual understanding and shared reflection at the
beginning, while still offering participants the space to explore and
represent their personal experiences through material engagement. This
balance emerges as one of the strengths of the format, supporting both
communal learning and individual insight.

children.name: Medical experts to clarify and contextualise symptoms
children.content:
Medical experts involved in the workshops contributed by clarifying
symptoms, contextualising bodily experiences, and reflecting on the
diagnostic process. One expert stated explicitly that, although they had
no personal experience of UTIs, their understanding derived from
treating many patients (P1, WS1). Drawing on this clinical perspective,
they distinguished between overlapping conditions, such as the
difference between UTIs and genital infections (P1, WS1), and explained
how Escherichia coli can be a normal bacterial presence that becomes
pathogenic, causing cystitis or even pyelonephritis when immune defences
are low (P1, WS1).

Experts also provided broader biomedical explanations, including the
definition of the urinary tract system and how infections in this system
differ from vaginal infections (P1, WS1). They described typical
diagnostic procedures, noting that physicians usually begin by assessing
general indicators such as fever, temperature, and shivering before
moving on to more specific signs, including bloody urine (P14, WS2).
These symptoms, they noted, are often shared with other conditions,
which complicates clinical reasoning and contributes to diagnostic
uncertainty (P14, WS2).

Beyond clinical clarification, experts reflected on the workshop itself.
One expert emphasised that, despite attempts to establish shared
definitions, each individual case remains unique and difficult to
reconcile with standardisation practices in healthcare (P1, WS1).
Another highlighted the value of the workshop for helping participants
recognise their symptoms, increase their awareness, and improve the way
they communicate their experience to medical professionals (P14, WS1).

These contributions position medical experts not only as providers of
clinical information but also as interpreters of the workshop’s
educational and communicative value, underscoring the role of medical
presence in supporting participants’ understanding and in enriching the
overall process of symptom articulation.

children.name: Misalignments in understanding
children.content:
Participants encountered several types of difficulties during the
workshop, particularly concerning language, materials, and understanding
the structure of the activities. A common issue related to translation
and vocabulary. Some participants did not recognise key medical terms
and explicitly asked for clarification. “What is this for?” asked one
participant, pointing to the term groin (P17, WS3), while another added,
“You know when you guys say the kick in the groin... that’s the groin.
It is there basically” (P16, WS3), attempting to explain the word to
others. Similarly, the term incontinence caused confusion: “What
incontinence mean?” (P12, WS2), “This is… incontinence? What is it?”
(P19, WS3), followed by an explanation: “When you cannot keep your… keep
it inside” (P18, WS3). In some cases, language barriers required
additional support: “I need a translator” (P18, WS3), and “I don’t know
how to say in Italian when you feel like... full” (P11, WS2).

Difficulties also emerged around the use of symptom labels. One
participant noted, “I cannot read them...” when referring to the tags
(Unidentified). Another hesitated to write on the wooden labels: “It is
not make it dirty…” (P18, WS3), expressing concern about damaging the
polished surface. Additionally, some participants found the number of
available labels limiting: “I feel like what I notice is we need
multiple of these” (P20, WS3), referring to the need for duplicate
labels to make multiple associations.

Regarding activity structure, participants often expressed uncertainty
about how to proceed. “What do you want us to do?” (Indistinct),
“Together?” (Participants), and “Are we linking with this or are we…”
(P13, WS2) illustrate recurring confusion. One participant asked, “So we
need to link those to their materials?” (P17), while another wondered,
“Do we start from symptoms or from a variable?” (P2, WS1). When asked
whether label associations were mandatory, a participant asked, “E io
non devo seguire questo per forza oppure sì?” (“And I do not have to
follow this, or do I?”) (P2, WS1). Representational challenges were also
raised: “It was difficult to represent all the symptoms in one” (P11,
WS2), and one participant noted, “For me, it was very difficult to
express pain” (G8, WS4).

These difficulties spanned both linguistic and structural aspects of the
workshop, highlighting the need for clearer guidance, flexible tools,
and accessible language throughout the process.

children.name: Was it useful in the end?
children.content:
Participants offered a range of responses to the workshop activities,
combining positive reactions, reflective insights, and critical
observations. Several expressed direct appreciation for the experience,
with comments such as “It was really funny” (G1, WS4) and “It was really
interesting” (G1, WS4). The materials themselves also received positive
remarks, as one participant noted, “I think this was quite cute” (G2,
WS4), referring to the physical components used during the shaping
process.

Many participants highlighted the novelty of the method. One remarked,
“I have never thought of associating symptoms with materials and their
characteristics” (G1, WS4), and later reflected, “I’m gonna think of it
\[symptom communication\] differently from now on” (G1, WS4). These
comments suggest that the workshop introduced an unfamiliar yet
stimulating approach to expressing bodily experience. Some participants
also wondered about the broader lineage of such methods, asking, “Do you
think that these shapes, the material and these textures, that you use
in your workshop, was it already, like, was it done somewhere here?”
(General). This curiosity indicates an interest in situating the
activity within a wider context of design or health-related practices.

Participants also proposed potential extensions or alternative formats.
One suggested that resembling a human shape might enhance communication,
asking, “I'm wondering if it could help to resemble a human shape in
this way because we \[are\] working this way” (G1, WS4). Others
connected the experience to personal practices of body awareness. One
participant recalled using drawing to process her ectopic pregnancy,
explaining, “In this moment I draw. I draw. In my body this is what is
happening” (G1, WS4), demonstrating how the workshop resonated with
pre-existing embodied methods of expression.

Not all feedback was positive. One participant questioned the relevance
of materialising symptoms for their own case: “Materializing it, um, for
me, there, I did not have a benefit from that, so I was wondering in
what ways does the materializing help people like me” (General). This
reflection underscores individual differences in the perceived
usefulness of the method and points to variation in how participants
relate to embodied forms of representation.

Overall, the feedback reveals a diverse spectrum of responses. While
many participants expressed enjoyment, curiosity, and reflective
engagement, others remained more critical or uncertain about the value
of materialising symptoms. Together, these reactions point to the
method’s potential while also highlighting areas for further adaptation
and exploration.
