children.name: Introduction
children.content:
This section draws together the main insights emerging from the analysis
and situates them within the aims and structure of the workshop format
and the methodology of this research. By consolidating these findings,
this section prepares the ground for the following chapter, where the
results are presented to medical experts to support their validation and
contextualisation.

children.name: 4.6.1 Opening and building the conversation
children.content:
The thematic analysis shows that participants engaged meaningfully with
both the topic of UTIs and the unconventional method of representing
symptoms through physical variables. The introductory activity, focused
on exploring the concept of symptom, proved effective in initiating
engagement. It allowed participants to situate themselves within the
topic, either by offering general interpretations or by sharing personal
and intimate accounts. Several concerns first raised during this
icebreaking phase resurfaced in later exercises, indicating a strong
thematic continuity throughout the workshop.

The participatory format played a fundamental role in promoting open
dialogue. Recruiting individuals with personal experiences of UTIs
fostered a sense of shared understanding, creating a safe space for
discussing sensitive topics. Group interactions stimulated peer support
and prompted rich descriptions of symptoms. In contrast, one-on-one
interactions with facilitators might have limited the emergence of such
detailed accounts, as participants often assumed mutual prior knowledge.
Speaking with peers encouraged unfiltered expression and prompted
spontaneous insights that would have been unlikely in a more formal,
hierarchical setting.

Language barriers, initially perceived as potential obstacles, proved
instead to be productive. The need to find alternative words led to
creative formulations and deeper reflection. This linguistic negotiation
enriched the descriptions and opened new paths to understanding symptoms
not just as medical facts but as experiences of every day.

At the same time, the workshop made visible that experience with illness
does not always guarantee clarity about one’s own condition. One
participant realised only during the activity that her recurring
symptoms were caused by candidiasis rather than cystitis. Another, with
no prior experience of UTIs, became an active listener, asking questions
that prompted collective reflection on disease origins, interpretations,
and treatments. These exchanges highlight how informal knowledge sharing
operates within group settings and reveal how misunderstandings can
shape personal narratives of disease, reinforcing the value of
collaborative interpretation.

The inclusion of medical professionals in the workshops aimed to
maintain focus, clarify medical ambiguities, and counter potential
misinformation. Experts also gained valuable insights into the patient's
perspective. Their active participation blurred traditional hierarchies,
especially when experts matched the demographic profile of participants
and adopted informal attitudes. One expert recognised the workshop’s
relevance to her own research on antibiotic resistance. Her feedback
highlighted how the activity helped participants recognise early
symptoms, enhancing self-management and potentially reducing
inappropriate antibiotic use.

Notably, the absence of a medical expert during the third session
negatively impacted both the accuracy of information and the clarity of
symptom differentiation. While the session proceeded, a lack of guidance
led to broader and less grounded conversations.

children.name: 4.6.2 Beyond material for body expression
children.content:
Materials played a primary role in enabling participants to communicate
sensitive or difficult topics. Physical components provided both a
symbolic and functional medium for expression. Participants often
translated bodily sensations into physical forms, referring to materials
instead of body parts. This distancing allowed greater freedom of
expression while prompting detailed reflection on symptom
characteristics. Exploring material features, such as texture,
temperature, and shape, stimulated nuanced dialogue around
symptomatology.

The material encouraged instinctive and metaphorical connections.
Participants assigned meaning to physical variables like sharpness,
smoothness, and weight, sometimes drawing from personal memories or
embodied experiences. Although the same symptom was represented by
different materials across participants, the reasoning often converged,
suggesting that the meaning resided more in the explanation than the
material itself.

While some participants embraced improvisation and reinterpretation of
materials, for example, using pegs as spikes or reappropriating
sandpaper, others were hindered by constraints such as limited material
choices or unclear instructions. The availability and presentation of
materials strongly shaped how smoothly participants could engage in the
activity. Glass, for example, was often mentioned as a desirable
addition because of its dual symbolic value: broken fragments were
associated with pain, while its translucent quality evoked uncertainty
or blurred perception. These symbolic associations further support the
hypothesis that materials function both literally and metaphorically in
the communication of symptoms.

Beyond materials, gestures also emerged as communicative strategies. For
instance, one participant simulated a creaking sound by mimicking the
action of rubbing polyether foam, evoking the discomfort of friction
without producing an actual sound. This observation raises questions
about gesture sonification and the extent to which communicative
variables are defined by actions rather than by the intrinsic properties
of materials. To further investigate how physicalization can trigger
sound within data representation, the workshop format was adapted and
conducted at the EKSIG conference (Budapest, 2025) in collaboration with
sonification expert Sara Lenzi. This experience broadened the scope of
the research to include related themes and yielded promising results,
which are intend to pursue in future research.

children.name: 4.6.3 Presentation of the representation
children.content:
The artefact presentations revealed different relationships to the
physical output. Some participants offered purely descriptive accounts,
while others used the artefact as a platform to narrate their lived
experiences. Naming conventions also varied, going from technical terms
like “artefact” to colloquial ones like “this” or “mine”, and further
reflecting the spectrum of attachment and interpretation.

Notably, those with recurrent or chronic symptoms tended to represent
their condition through timelines, reconstructing sequences of events to
make sense of their illness. In contrast, experts often produced
simplified or symbolic artefacts with fewer components, emphasizing
clarity over detail. This divergence points to differing communicative
goals and levels of familiarity with the embodied aspects of illness.

Communication strategies varied across sessions, with participants
drawing on vocal negation, metaphor, and comparison to clarify the
intent behind their representations or to differentiate their work from
group tendencies. At times, participants described states of well-being
to contrast with dysfunction, using oppositional reasoning to highlight
what the body should feel like in order to emphasise what it does feel
like during illness. These contrasting formulations reveal an elaborated
approach, showing how participants negotiated meaning by moving between
what is present and what is absent, what is ordinary and what is
altered.

Minor issues emerged regarding some of the tools adopted for the
activity. For example, the empty labels intended for annotating extra
symptoms and variables were underused due to their polished appearance,
which discouraged participants from writing on them. Clearer
instructions and demonstrations could resolve such issues in future
iterations.

Despite episodes of confusion or ambiguity, the workshop format
encouraged meaningful engagement, fostered reflection, and supported
participants in articulating their experiences of illness. The use of
material as a communicative medium proved particularly valuable,
revealing forms of insight that often remain inaccessible through verbal
description alone. At the same time, the challenges participants faced
in manipulating and interpreting materials point to the need for
cultivating tactile literacy, a capacity that remains far less developed
and discussed than visual communication.

children.name: 4.6.4 Generative physical variables to map symptoms
children.content:
Finally, the analysis demonstrates that physical variables are central
to participants’ capacity to externalise and communicate bodily
experiences, serving both as conceptual and expressive tools. Throughout
the workshops, a set of recurring associations emerged with notable
consistency. Weight was commonly used to express severity or burden.
Sharpness developed from general roughness into pointed, peak-like forms
that marked pain. Spherical shapes often represented general, ambiguous,
or early symptoms, whereas irregular or unstable structures conveyed
uncertainty, diagnostic ambiguity, or emotional instability. In one
particularly striking example, a participant constructed an artefact
designed to collapse on touch, using its intentional destructibility to
embody the fragile nature of her condition.

However, these associations were neither systematic nor prescriptive.
Variables functioned not as fixed indicators but as negotiated
affordances, shaped by context, interpretation, and material
availability. Participants adapted the same variable to different ends,
sometimes proceeding by metaphors (e.g., permeability to suggest body
leakage or disease lack of control) and at other times by indexes (e.g.,
red to signal the presence of blood or temperature for fever). This dual
possibility underscores the interpretive potential of variables and
their embeddedness in personal narratives.

As participants interacted with the materials, variables emerged as
situated constructs rather than fixed categories, shaped by expressive
intentions and by what each component afforded. Participants did not
treat variables as stable qualities. Instead, properties shifted as part
of the interaction and became performative rather than inherent. A
feature such as softness or sharpness could carry different meanings
depending on how it was manipulated. Gestures such as rubbing a surface
to create sound, layering components to produce instability, or
arranging pieces to suggest growth expanded the communicative role of
variables beyond their initial encoding function. These observations
show that variables emerge through process, interaction, and temporality
rather than from intrinsic material qualities, reinforcing the thesis’s
initial framing of materiality in physicalization as an active and
situated form of engagement.

The analysis revealed that participants not only associated specific
physical variables with symptoms but also began to organise these
associations into layered and interrelated structures. This indicates
that variables are not perceived as isolated elements. Instead, they are
understood as part of a system of meaning, where some variables take on
foundational roles and others provided nuance or further specification.
A clear example emerged in the way roughness was described not as an
independent variable, but as a refinement of discomfort, which itself
was embodied through shape. In this structure, shape operates as a
broader container of meaning (for instance, denoting pain or tension),
while roughness narrows the expression to a specific quality of that
discomfort, such as how it feels on the surface or how intense it is.
This kind of nested association suggests that participants were
intuitively building semantic hierarchies, even without formal
instruction. Similar to the role of grammar in language, some variables
functioned as primary descriptors in participants’ use of physical
materials, while others operated as modifiers that added depth, context,
or specificity to the representation.

By distinguishing between what could be called primary and secondary
variables, participants were engaging in an expressive logic. This logic
enabled them to build internal coherence across the elements they
selected, even when the materials and instructions were open-ended.
Rather than treating all variables as equal, they prioritised some as
central to the message and others as supporting elements. This reflects
an emergent grammar or syntax of physical expression as a set of
unspoken rules or preferences that governed how meaning is constructed
within the physicalization process.

However, this process also revealed the limits of the predefined
variable set. Certain terms, such as “three-dimensional form” or
“fuzziness”, were either misunderstood or resisted. Variables like
colour were repeatedly appropriated across categories, used not only for
visual qualities but also as carriers for temperature, urgency, or
psychological state. This blurring of boundaries indicates that
participants did not treat variables as discrete, isolated dimensions,
but rather as multifunctional communicative devices.

Together, these findings suggest that the act of variable selection and
use is not a process of classification, but a form of situated reasoning
and a negotiation between personal experience, social context, and
material constraint. Variables provided a structure for expression, but
one that remained open-ended and generative rather than prescriptive.
Their value lay not in standardisation, but in their capacity to
accommodate plurality, ambiguity, and affect within a physical language
of symptoms.

From a design perspective, this positions variables not merely as
descriptors but as epistemic tools that help participants make sense of,
and give form to, experiences that are otherwise difficult to
articulate. The vocabulary that emerges from this work is a living
lexicon, grounded in practice and responsive to context. This
orientation shifts the focus from designing communication tools about
illness to designing with illness as it is contextualised, narrated, and
reshaped within participatory settings. In this view, illness becomes
something understood through interaction, reflection, and collective
interpretation, rather than a static object to be represented.

As such, this research contributes to the broader field of data
physicalization by proposing an expanded view of variables as
relational, performative, and open to appropriation. Future applications
could embrace this complexity by incorporating gesture-driven elements,
supporting multi-modal associations, and allowing participants to
articulate new variables on their own terms. Rather than offering a
fixed set of options, the aim becomes to design approaches and materials
that evolve alongside the interpretive practices they support.

The analysis presented in this chapter establishes how participants
externalised, compared, and interpreted their embodied experiences
through physical variables and material engagement. To understand how
these participant-led insights relate to clinical knowledge, the next
chapter examines the assessment conducted with medical experts. Their
evaluation focuses on the workshop topics concerning UTIs and related
conditions, offering an essential perspective on the clarity, relevance,
and potential clinical value of the expressions generated during the
sessions . By grounding the findings in medical interpretation, this
validation phase helps situate the participatory outcomes within
established healthcare understandings. Following this assessment,
Chapter 6 deepens the discussion by examining how physical variables
operate as mechanisms for perception and communication within
participatory data physicalization, highlighting their interpretive and
generative role in bridging lived experience with medical reasoning .
Building on this, Chapter 7 introduces the physical variable apparatus,
which consolidates the methodological insights of the thesis into a
structured system for eliciting, organising, and interpreting embodied
data across participatory healthcare contexts.
